publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

it may be Paston. There is very little to distinguish him
from other people. He has no l particular expression; no
we cannot imagine what will he [clings?] to the only

that the emptiness of England: the scarcity of people; the
predominance of individuals. We can count the ships
Everything belongs to the Queen. We can count her
possessions– a few ships, a few palaces. She is the
parliament, press, society, law, order. But the
man himself, the individual, has the greatest
is cumbered, stiff, constrained, with & still: Not so
very long ago, words are still writing is still
an expressive, a luxurious art. She does not
scribble words are Writing is still an art that
requires great ceremony. Their What you make with the pen is
separate from what you say with the tongue.
Only a few years back, words were written beautifully
on in by scribes on parchment; & the leaves
when bound up, were chained to the lectern; &
only you read & read in great physical discomfort,
seats at on ahard bench, in a in in the cold.

In him then we have the rudiments of all the books

p.l: It is the printing press that splits this brings confusion. For
It is the printing press that makes writing so so
many headed, so many limbed, so incoherent &
barbed & streaked, a [mongrel?] with so many different parents
that it is requires a whole army of learned people
& a perpetual procession of fine tasters, to keep any
hold on its manifestations. From the printing press
The Presses of London & Oxford & Durham & [illeg.] – the
presses that were printing in copy & [carting?] [illeg.]

cheap legible books that anyone
cd could read, were not nice

feeders, They were Anything that could be written
cd. could be printed
and, whereas music & painting any thought, any
morality, any record, any discourse – whatever passed
through the brain of man, it was whatever he worked to
argue out, to pressure, to put on record – all this became
printed matter. And there The restraint was in his [illeg.]
in himself alone. He When he was still only Harrison, only Paston,
he could not put into words he was He cou Much was un
inexpressible; much was He perhaps non existent Very They
should be [illeg.] the [illeg.] of the printing press can make
the writer say what is upon him. Music, & painting were
thus exerting their pressure too. Spenser half [yield?] to the
fascination of the other art. Music makes the old songs
limits the poet to write what can be sung. This is why
the a [shade?] still shrouds the [nose?] & the eyes & the hands
a simple
Unlike the painter or the [sculptor?], the writer is exposed to
innumerable, outlying, inappropriate, irrelevant
solicitations. Why not write the history of your parish?
or the life of some Roman Emperor? Or
compliment your patron? Why not take part in the [illeg.] of your
country? And advise the soul of its dangers? Why not
become pamphleter, historian, [illeg.]? – There is the
press, ready to accept anything. And as the public becomes
more learned, as glass is filled into windows & pillows
be replace logs, the public adds its invitation to the
writer – It is an inquisitve, active minded
public, & it soon duplicates the writer takes hold of
Anon, & makes him into the familiar voice,
with which talks an easy subject: only a few
keep to the old art way: & still persist in
giving to words a certain making words into works of art,
the author
